sen.j: 紋付（もんつき）とは家紋の入った着物のこと。
sen.e: "Montsuki" refers to "kimono" (Japanese traditional clothing) that has some family crests on itself.

sen.j: 紋付という言葉には二義あり、一つは紋の入った着物一般もしくは着物に紋が入っていることを指して用い、もう一つは特に男物の紋付小袖の略称として用いる。
sen.e: More concretely, the word montsuki is used in two different ways, and one is the word that means the common kimono with some family crests on itself (or the style of kimono that has some family crests on itself), and the other is the word that is used as the abbreviation of "montsuki kosode" (a narrow-sleeved kimono for men with some family crests on itself).

More specifically, the word "montsuki" is used in two different ways: one is the word that means the common kimono with some family crests on itself (or the style of kimono that has some family crests on itself), and the other is the word used as an abbreviation for "montsuki kosode" (a narrow-sleeved kimono for men, emblazoned with family crests).

sen.j: しかし、紋付とのみ言った場合には後者のほうが一般的で、羽織、裃、女ものの着物は含まれない。
sen.e: Commonly, "montsuki" means the latter, and it does not include "haori" (a Japanese half coat), "kamishimo" (samurai costume, or old ceremonial costume), nor women's kimono.

sen.j: 紋付小袖の起源は江戸時代初期にあるとされる。
sen.e: Montsuki kosode began to be worn in the early Edo period, they say.

sen.j: それまで正装の際に用いる小袖は熨斗目小袖が一般的であったが、これの略式として五つ紋の入った無地もしくは熨斗目の小袖を用いることが行われるようになった。
sen.e: Until then, the kosode used in general as the formal attire had been "noshime kosode" (kosode with 'noshime' [check-pattern or lateral-striped pattern woven into the lower part of the sleeves and the waist part]), but from then, the solid color kosode - though it had five family crests on itself - began to be used along with noshime kosode.
sen.cmt: ・「熨斗目（のしめ）小袖」とは「熨斗目模様のある小袖」（熨斗目模様の内容は後述）の意味で使われているように思われます。
sen.e: Until then, the kosode generally used as formal attire had been "noshime kosode" (kosode with 'noshime' [a check pattern or laterally striped pattern woven into the lower part of the sleeves and the waist part]), but from then the solid-color kosode--though it had five family crests--began to be used along with noshime kosode.

sen.j: 紋付小袖は、武家社会では略装の裃や羽織袴などのような準礼装にもっぱら用いられた。
sen.e: In the samurai society, montsuki kosode was coordinated merely with the semi-formal attire - in other words, simplified version of kamishimo or "haori-hakama" (the combination of haori and 'hakama' [loose-legged pleated trousers]).
sen.cmt: ・一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In samurai society, montsuki kosode was coordinated merely with semi-formal attire, or in other words a simplified version of kamishimo or "haori-hakama" (the combination of haori and 'hakama' [loose-legged, pleated trousers]).

sen.j: 下級の武士や町人においては次第にこれが礼装もしくは最礼装として扱われるようになり、明治の勲章着用規定によって男子の第一礼装の際に紋付小袖を用いることが定められるにいたった。
sen.e: And montsuki kosode began to be worn as the formal - sometimes, utmost formal - attire among low-level samurai and merchants, and at last during the Meiji period, it was established as the top formal attire in a provision of wearing decorations.
sen.cmt: ・一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: And montsuki kosode began to be worn as the formal--sometimes the most formal--attire among low-level samurai and merchants, and finally during the Meiji period it was established as the top formal attire in the provision for wearing decorations.

sen.j: その形状は通常の小袖（長着）と特に異なるところはなく、背中の中央部、両袖の後側、両胸の部分に紋が入っているところが特徴である。
sen.e: Montsuki kosode has the same shape as that of the common kosode (called "nagagi" [full-length garments]), and the characteristic of montsuki kosode is the family crests - one crest is on its center of the back, two on its sleeves' back symmetrically, and two on the chest symmetrically.

Montsuki kosode has the same shape as that of the common kosode (called "nagagi" [full-length garments]), and the characteristic of montsuki kosode is the use of family crests: - one at the center of the back, two situated symmetrically on the backs of the sleeves, and two symmetrically on the chest.

sen.j: 以上の五箇所に紋があるものを五つ紋と呼び、これが正式の紋付小袖のかたちである（これは大紋の紋の入れ方を受継いだもの）。
sen.e: This montsuki kosode, called "itsutsu-mon" (five-crests type), is the formal style, which is modeled after the style of "daimon" (crested formal robe in the Edo period).
sen.cmt: ・一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: This montsuki kosode, called "itsutsu-mon" (five-crest type), is the formal style, which is modeled after the style of "daimon" (a crested formal robe of the Edo period).

sen.j: 両袖を略した三つ紋、背中の紋のみの一つ紋の紋付もあり、準礼装として通用する。
sen.e: And "mitsu-mon" (three-crests type) - the two crests on the sleeves' back are removed - and "hitotsu-mon" (one-crest type), which has only one crest on the back, also go as the semi-formal attire.
sen.cmt: ・一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: And "mitsu-mon" (three-crest type)--in which the two crests on the sleeves' back are removed--and "hitotsu-mon" (single-crest type), which has only one crest on the back, are also semi-formal attire.

sen.j: 小袖の模様は熨斗目もしくは無地であるが、現在では無地のみが用いられ、熨斗目小袖の紋付は歌舞伎や時代劇の衣装として残るのみである。
sen.e: Montsuki kosode has two types about its pattern - the type of solid color, and the type of noshime - and at present, only the solid color kosode is used among the public, and noshime kosode is seen just in Kabuki or in historical dramas.
sen.cmt: ・ここに言う「熨斗目」は明らかに「模様」の一種です。そしてこれは、下記HPに説明されている熨斗目模様（＝「袖の下部分と腰部分に織り出された格子縞や横縞」）を指すように思われます。 [http://www.bb.em-net.ne.jp/maccafushigi/mac/18.htm]
sen.e: Montsuki kosode has two types of patterns: the solid-color type and noshime type; today, however, only the solid-color kosode is used among the public, and noshime kosode is seen just in Kabuki or historical dramas.

sen.j: 裃において無地の紋付小袖を用いることは江戸期においては略装であったが、現在では正式の着用方法として行われている。
sen.e: In the Edo period, it meant informal dressing to use the solid color montsuki kosode as kamishimo, but at present, it is recognized as the formal dressing.
In the Edo period, one's manner of dress was informal if it used the solid-color montsuki kosode as kamishimo, but today it's recognized as formal dress.

sen.j: 生地は木綿、絹などがあるが、最礼式は羽二重と呼ばれる特殊な絹織物で、無地の場合、色は黒が正式とされる。
sen.e: The natural substance of montsuki kosode is cotton, silk, or others, and the best-quality cloth used for the kosode is the special silk cloth called "habutae" (a smooth, glossy silk cloth woven finely), and habutae's formal color is black when the solid color type is chosen.
sen.cmt: ・原文では、「木綿」「絹」といった未加工の材料も、「羽二重」のような手を加えた後の織物・布地も特に区別することなく「生地」と捉えられているようです。しかし英語ではこの点訳し分けるべきで、翻訳者は前者を"natural substance"、後者を"cloth"としています。（参照：Longman Dictionary of Contemporary English)
sen.e: The natural substance of montsuki kosode is cotton, silk or another material, while the best-quality cloth used for the kosode is the special silk cloth called "habutae" (a smooth, glossy silk cloth that's finely woven), and habutae's formal color is black when the solid-color type is chosen.

sen.j: もっとも夏着は絽や紗で仕立て、洒落着として縮緬が用いられることもあり、色も特に戦後は渋い中間色を中心に色紋付が行われることがある。
sen.e: Occasionally, however, the summer wear is woven with "ro" (a kind of silk gauze) or "sha" (another kind of silk gauze), and "chirimen" (silk crepe) is used to make a stylish wear, and "iro-montsuki" (montsuki kosode that has a color other than black - mainly, a subdued, neutral color) has become to be seen particularly after World War Ⅱ.

sen.j: 黒羽二重の生地は最初から黒を染めるのではなく、下染めのうえから黒をかけることによって深みのある色を出し、下染めに用いられる染料によって生地の上下が定まる。
sen.e: The cloth of "kuro-habutae" (black-colored habutae) is dyed black not at first but after the bottoming, which makes the black deeper, and the dye used in bottoming decides the rank of the cloth.

sen.j: 特に高価とされるのはアイ (植物)や紅の下染めで、なかでも藍の下染めを用いた羽二重は「甕のぞき」として珍重される。
sen.e: The kuro-habutae that undergoes the bottoming with the indigo or safflower is particularly expensive, and of the two, the indigo-dyed habutae is extremely valued as "kame nozoki" (the cloth of a light blue dyed in a short period of time).
sen.cmt: ・「甕のぞき」とは下記HPによれば「ごく薄い水色の生地」を指し、「藍の甕をのぞきこむぐらいのごく短時間で染める」ところにその名前の由来があります。[http://www.zensenken.gr.jp/jiten/jiten_main.html]

sen.j: 羽二重の生地は紋となるべき部分を白い円のまま残して染められる。
sen.e: The cloth of habutae is dyed except for the circular part which should be filled with the family crest.

sen.j: この円のことを石持ちと呼び、江戸期の安価な紋付の場合、紋を入れずにそのまま仕立てることもあった（このような紋付を石持ちの紋付と呼ぶ）が、現在ではめったに用いられない。
sen.e: This circular part is called "ishimoch" - and the montsuki that has such an ishimochi is called "ishimochi no montsuki" - and in the Edo period, a cheap montsuki had no ishimochi on its cloth, but at present, such ishimochi-free montsuki is rarely seen.
sen.cmt: ・「紋付」なのに「紋を入れずにそのまま仕立てる」のは変にも思えますが、この点、2つ先の文章にあるとおり「紋を後から刺繍で入れる」ということです。 ・原文の括弧書きは、前後の文脈とのつながりが悪いように思われますので、位置を変えダッシュで挟みつつ訳出しています。

sen.j: 紋付を仕立てる場合には、この石持ちのある羽二重の生地を買い、購入者の注文に合わせて紋を染めてから仕立てるために、ふつうの着物のような仕立て代のほかに紋入れの代金が必要となる。
sen.e: To get montsuki made, you need to buy the cloth of habutae that has the ishimochi on itself, and then you also need to pay extra for the crest-dyeing, because the crest is custom-designed.
sen.cmt: ・文末の"custom-designed" は「特注のデザインである」の意味です（原文の「購入者の注文に合わせて紋を染めてから仕立てる」の部分に相当します。）

sen.j: このため、安価に紋付をつくるために石持ちのない羽二重生地を買って、紋は刺繍で入れる方法もある。
sen.e: To get it made in a lower price, you can buy the habutae cloth that has no ishimochi and get the crest woven into the cloth.
